We could interleave the schedule in such a way that the highest staked validators are not adjacent but, say, 1 or 2 slots apart from each other, and then we'd stick the small-but-honest validators in between. Then it would no longer make sense to kill the machines between the tests if it's rented from a provider with hourly billing and a minimum 1h billing per session. Also, the validators with a higher stake would appear more often in the roster, proportionally a higher amount of time than the little validators, almost to a point where it's more profitable to get weights from the small ones which only want a few minutes per day as opposed to huge valis which can occupy an executor for 6h/day

I'm not fully following you. This average time is computed across all miners and executor. It's exactly the same for all executors and miners
There is also the case that miner that finish job shorter than average job send time will have lower score than the miner that finish job that's slightly high/equal  than average job time.

Let's say average job send time is 13 seconds. 
Miner 1 finish the job in 12 seconds. Since it's negative, it's considered as 1sec and have score 1. 
Miner 2 finish the job in 13.01 seconds. Since it's not negative, it'll have 0.01 time took and have 10+ score for a single job.
So some miner can control this kind of average job send time by delaying the communication.
are they doing a parallel solve coupled with a timing attack to aim just above the average and get a score higher than from a 1s solve?
That attack might work, but it requires a lot of very exact timings, and we haven't found a way to influence average job send time, but it might be possible with TCP level manipulation

We will remove this average time bonus since it does indeed introduce a non-linearity in scoring, and any such thing is exploitable. The reason it was added was to avoid the real cases where because of slow validator upload speeds, legit miners which finish the hashcat jobs in 43 seconds would still fail the 54 sec timeout because the validator took 20 sec to push out all the zipped passwords
anyway, can we remove that bonus and see if it mitigates?

it kind of is, but instead of doing it 100 times for each hash yuu would only need to do it once
I'm not an expert in hashcat internals but I'm pretty sure that's what hashcat is doing. Generating a password, hashing it, and then matching it against ALL target hashes, not one at a time.
hm yea probably it does that already

actually it makes a lot of sense to solve hashcat faster than average sending time. let's suppose avergage solving time is 30 seconds. average sending time is 15 seconds. all who solve hashcat in 30 seconds get x2 bonus, as their task solving speed is 15 seconds with bonus. but those who solved it it 15 seconds or less will get task solving time of 1 second. this is x15 bonus. if you guess average sending time and could solve in 15.0001 seconds, you get like thousands times increased bonus
look at the average sending times posted above. they have wide variance, I don't see how you can guess them reliably to more than a few hundred ms

When multiple requests load increases

actually it should give you a considerable bonus.
let's say you have 4 gpus and solve each task separately for 40 seconds
in that case you will get a score of 1/40 *4 = 0.1

now let's try parallelise one job on those 4 gpus
you solve it in 10 seconds, so you get a score of 0.1, but you still have 40 seconds to continue
next job will give you 0.05, next 0.033, next 0.025 and final one 0.02
so instead of score 0.1 you will get 0.1 + 0.05 + 0.033 + 0.025 + 0.02 = 0.228

that's more than double. you can also have 8 or 16 gpus to improve this further

the goal is for miners to submit optimized inference pipelines(optimized in terms of performance, efficiency, or power/vram usage), and validators go through each submission daily and benchmarks them
the validators are split into two parts, the validation portion and the benchmarking API
- the validation portion collects submissions everyday and sends them to the API for benchmarking
- the API tests submissions and continuously reports benchmark results back as it does work, it's separated to limit the scope of access for submissions as much as possible
if the API isn't done with a day's batch of submissions by the next day, it will simply continue working on whichever submissions still need to be tested the day after(along with invalidating any benchmarks for changed submissions), this does however mean that it can take an increasingly long amount of time for validators to set weights, depending on the amount of load at hand

hey @Rhef the job timing system is bugged, after the average send time removal thing was turned off, the timings on the jobs are not even anymore
the time used to calculate how long a job took is based off of the first job sent, not calculated individually from what it seems
so when a uid has lots of executors, the last job to be received has much less time to complete than the first one
first job received @ 0:00 and takes 45s to complete, the time took returns as 45s. last job received at 0:20 and takes the same 45s to complete, time took is 65s and counts as fail
I have been seeing this behavior as well
This is because we are trying to send a massive amount of jobs over in a very short period of time, we are talking >10k now, it is going to bottleneck whatever we do
Fortunately the new job sending system uses s3 to send out jobs, so we just send tiny links and the miner can fetch it by itself
You can't overload s3
This system will initially be used for the LLM-based validation, where without this nothing would really work
However there is some potential to use it for hashcat jobs as well. I hoped it won't be necessary, but from what you are saying, it looks like we might need to use it here too.

what is the postgres db even used for

was a bit lazy so I asked this question to Claude posting it models.py from repo from validator:

```
it appears this PostgreSQL database is used for a complex system involving blockchain validators, miners, and job execution. Here's a high-level overview of what the database is used for in this project:

1. System Event Logging: The SystemEvent model tracks various events in the system, such as weight setting successes/failures, job outcomes, and validator actions.

2. Miner Management: The Miner and MinerBlacklist models keep track of miners in the network, including their hotkeys and blacklist status.

3. Cycle and Batch Management: The Cycle and SyntheticJobBatch models manage scheduling and execution of synthetic jobs at specific blockchain blocks.

4. Job Tracking: OrganicJob and SyntheticJob models track different types of jobs executed by miners, including their status, scores, and related information.

5. Admin Job Requests: The AdminJobRequest model allows administrators to create and manage custom job requests for miners.

6. Receipt Management: JobFinishedReceipt and JobStartedReceipt models store information about job execution, including timing and scoring.

7. Weight Management: The Weights model tracks the weights set by validators at specific blocks, which is crucial for the blockchain's consensus mechanism.

8. Prompt and Workload Management: PromptSeries, SolveWorkload, PromptSample, and Prompt models manage the generation, distribution, and solving of prompts used in synthetic jobs.

Overall, this database serves as the backbone for a complex distributed system that involves blockchain operations, job scheduling and execution, miner management, and prompt-based workloads. It's designed to support a validator network that likely processes both organic and synthetic jobs while maintaining a scoring and weighting system for miners.
```

update: a performance fix for hashcat-based jobs has just been assigned and the work on it has started. It's a small change which will move out sending the volume which contains passwords to the JobInitialRequest, but the miner will need a new argument from JobRequest to start the actual work
now interestingly some of you might notice that this new argument will be prefixed by the miner hotkey

it is not really a part of the official protocol, but if someone is concerned about relay mining, they can check if the hotkey in that argument matches their hotkey and refuse to do the request.
